Olvera Street remains one of the most beautiful, and historic, remnants of early California. It's a gorgeous street, filled with artisan pushcarts and stands of hand crafted Mexican themed crafts and baked goods. Either side of the street is lined with Mexican folk art shops and very good Mexican restaurants. The street sports the oldest original house in California (Mexico at the time) and spans history, from the catacombs where the Chinese workers who built California's railroads were warehoused, to the church where they bless the animals once a year. Plaques along the way tell you what you are looking at. A sunny afternoon on Olvera Street should not be missed. And Chinatown is around the corner, in case you prefer Tsing Tao to Margaritas.

Olvera Street is one of those L.A. mainstays that everybody must visit. Yes, yes, it is kind of a weird, tourist style street but there is something about this place that is truly fun.

Like most people from L.A. I have been coming here as long as I can remember. As a child, I loved it. There are a bunch of business stalls that line the center of the street. And, it has been that way forever. Through the years what they sell in these stalls has changed with the times but, though the items have changed, the overall visual feeling and energy of this place has not changed at all. It is the same as when I came here as a child.

To the sides of the stalls are the businesses that are located in actual structures. Within these stores you will find a wide variety of curiosity items and things you never knew that you wanted or needed. Overall, in terms of shopping, this is a great place to find that unique gift that is truly something different from the norm.

There are also several restaurants that line the interior of Olvera Street. They are all, obliviously, Mexican cuisine orientated. Each one is a unique place to dine. There are a couple larger, dine in style resultants, and several food stall. Each offers a unique interpretation of Cali-Mex Food.

Overall, fun place. You never know who or what you will see and what fun you may have.

Olvera Street Historic Marketplace of Los Angeles

Olvera Street was created in 1930 “to preserve and present the customs and trades of early California." Many of the merchants on Olvera Street today are descended from the original vendors. Olvera Street in Los Angeles, California is also known as the :El Pueblo Historical Monument, Calle Olvera, and La Placita Olvera! Known as “the birthplace of Los Angeles,” is a Mexican Marketplace. Olvera Street is a block-long narrow, tree-shaded, brick-lined market with old structures, painted stalls, street vendors, cafes, restaurants and gift shops.

Olvera Street is the oldest street in Los Angeles. It is now not so much a "street" as a series of restaurants and individual stalls that all sell the same cheap merchandise all made in China. We're talking child "guitars", Mexican dresses, cheap whistles, purses, plastic toys, etc. Each stall sells the same thing the last stall was selling, so don't worry if you saw something you might be interested in buying, you'll see it again in another 10 feet. The stall proprietors are in my many experiences here, not friendly but watch you like a hawk with a suspicious eye. The worst thing about Olvera Street is how inauthentic it is. It could be amazing if there were real Mexican craftsmen selling their products, homemade tortilla makers, etc. but I suspect these stalls are granfathered ownership plots and there is no way to fix this problem. On the other hand, there are a couple of very good restaurants here at opposite ends of the street. My favorite is Cielito Lindo which has been open since the 1930's - it's not a sit-down restaurant although there are a few tables for a quick sit. The taquito plate is a must - that is their speciality! The line snaking across the plaza moves quickly and speaks to the quality and popularity of Cielito Lindo. It;s the only reason I ever come to Olvera Street. It's worth a visit if you're interested in having the most amazing taquitos you've ever tasted, but if you want authentic Mexican/American merchandise and history, you'll have to look elsewhere.

SADLY AN OVERRATED, COMMERCIALIZED AND SOMEWHAT TRASHING “HISTORIC CENTER”

Compared to the OK Corral in Tombstone, Arizona or Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia, Olvera Street as a “historic center” is a huge disappointment and has become a huge commercialized taco stand. Except for Old Plaza Church, Avila Adobe built in 1818, Pelanconi House built in 1857, and the Sepulveda House built in 1887, the rest of the “pueblo” is a waste of time. Touted by the city of Los Angeles as "A Mexican Street of Yesterday in a City of Today", Olvera Street is an urban joke and a fake display of a “historic village”.Olvera Street is an example of underfunding, mismanagement, lack of maintenance and municipal bumbling. An example: on a Saturday around noon following a mass, the church was closed for two hours to clean the church. When I asked the custodian why we could not enter the church while the employees were cleaning, she replied that the church was closed out of respect for the cleaners who did not want visitors to see them cleaning the church -- LA is politically correct. However, if you are in the area to visit the Union Station or to eat a French Dip at Philippe’s, take an hour or so to visit Olvera Street.

Step back in time, to the year 1818 to a charming block in Downtown LA known as Olvera Street. An old time square, which is lined with dancing couples serenaded by the broadcasted or live music, surrounds the 100 year old trees and authentic cultural vendors. Once inside the rustic gates that tote, "The Birthplace of Los Angeles," the Avila Adobe house is tucked inside. Tour the original home that is among the modern day buildings of Downtown LA. Also, is a Catholic Church founded not long after with a museum in the basement that typically showcases artists, history, and holidays meaningful to the culture. Amazingly, this is a small block of history that all should visit not only for educational reasons, but for the culture that is so prevelant and meaningful in this city. (Parking and restrooms are across the street in a dedicated parking area for about $10) Olvera Street is a must see for all!
